newsitem.title: USA: Widespread showers in U.S. Midwest, more next week.
newsitem.headline: Widespread showers in U.S. Midwest, more next week.

text.p: Widespread showers fell from eastern Nebraska to Indiana the past 24 hours and more were forecast for Thursday, which should halt spring planting for a few days, grain dealers and meteorologists said.
Western Midwest areas turn dry Friday and eastern areas Saturday, but rain should return early next week.
"The outlook for Saturday is mostly fair, with partly cloudy skies," said Joel Burgio, meteorologist for Weather Services Corp.

Near freezing temperatures should enter southern Minnesota and northern Iowa late Thursday and early Friday, and then across southern Wisconsin and northern Illinois late Friday and early Saturday. However, Burgio said crops there should not be harmed by the cold.

Burgio said 0.5 to 1.0 inch of rain fell in central and eastern Iowa, northern Illinois and southern Wisconsin the past 24 hours with lesser amounts in Missouri, central Illinois and northern Indiana, and Ohio.

Fred Gesser, Weather Express Inc meteorologist, said eastern Iowa and northwest Illinois should receive another 0.5 to 2.0 inches Thursday, and 0.25 to 1.0 inch from eastern Nebraska and western Iowa.

"Between Sunday and Tuesday, the central Plains and much of the Corn Belt will receive 1/2 to two inches of rain with 80 percent coverage," said Gesser. "The Rockies to the east coast is going to be very wet (next week)."
Rain will spread across the hard red winter wheat areas from Kansas to north Texas, with the dry areas of western Kansas likely to receive beneficial amounts, Gesser said.
Up to two inches may fall Monday to Wednesday in Oklahoma, which follows 0.25 to 1.5 inches expected by Thursday.
"I think Oklahoma will have too much rain," Gesser said.
